text: hello my name is Jimmy Bay and I'm a
prototyping Solutions architect at AWS
this video is part of a series of videos
about the OPA on AWS open- Source
solution to provide AWS related
functionality in your backstage
developer platform in this video we're
going to dive deeper into environment
providers in Opa to describe what they
are and how you can build and contribute
your own provider to customize the
solution as described in previous videos
Opa on AWS is an open- Source solution
to help customers build their internal
developer platform and integrate with
AWS the OPA solution provides the
infrastructure as code to run backstage
in AWS provides backstage plugins
reference implementations for source
code management using gitlab and an
example repository containing samples of
environment environment provider and
software
templates so let's take a look at an
overview of typical workflows and use
cases for environments and application
deployment using Opa on
AWS we have a platform engineering team
the platform engineering role includes
responsibilities to define the
infrastructure where business
applications can be run and can be
accessed by clients and end users in an
AWS Cloud scenario this includes setting
up accounts Network routing rules
storage compute run times monitoring
access permissions and other resources
so that they comply with corporate and
Industry standards and
regulations using Opa on AWS the
platform engineer can use their
preferred infrastructures code like
terraform cdk or cloud formation to
build standardized compliant and
reusable assets for how an environment
for applications should be modeled this
code can then be wrapped into backstage
templates for environment and enironment
provider types and made available
through the backstage platform and once
the templates are in backstage they can
now be used to repeatedly Stamp Out
multiple environments across multiple
accounts and regions for various
departments by way of gitl
pipelines with the environments prepared
by the platform engineering team and
available in backstage the application
developers can now use Opa on AWS and
backstage to create new applications
with corresponding git repositories and
pipelines to easily deploy them into
Target environments now we cover a lot
more detail about the application
developer experience in another video so
I encourage you to check that additional
video in this series for now let's take
a Clos look at what's in an environment
provider that the platform engineer
builds and how that process
works what I'll describe in this
overview is typical of an environment
provider supplied in the OPA on AWS
solution as a reference example as we
inspect what makes up an environment
provider it's important to remember that
all of these AWS resources will need to
be
provisioned behind an environment
provider is simply infrastructure is
code to provision resources if you need
different resources or policies than
those provided in the solution it's
absolutely possible to modify the code
or write one to meet your needs an
environment provider starts with a
Target account where applications should
be deployed in this account there will
be two key roles created the
provisioning role is intended to be
assumed by a cicd pipeline and will
provision application resources into the
environment this role is used when
creating new applications or when
modifications to application
infrastructure
occur the operations role is used when
performing actions against your
application resources for example if you
modify the application's environment
variable configuration stop or start the
application or retrieve application logs
then the operations role will be used to
perform those types of actions it's
important to keep in mind the
distinction between these two roles so
that the appropriate set of policies are
attached to these roles and avoid having
them be overly
permissive
an environment provider will also
contain region specific resources SSM
parameters will contain configuration
information about the environment
Secrets manager stores any secrets and
KMS keys are used for encrypting data
there's also an audit table created for
the environment provider which is used
to store audit entries capturing actions
performed against the resources and
applications that run in the environment
provider and then within the region the
environment provider Provisions network
resources
including a VPC one or more subnets
routing tables and security groups also
provisioned will be the runtime
environment each environment provider
typically provides a single runtime
environment to support running
containerized applications for example
there may be an ECS cluster provisioned
or if the intention is to run kubernetes
pods then possibly an eks cluster would
be
provisioned with a high level
understanding of what an environment
provider encapsulates let's look at what
it takes to surface an environment in
backstage
the OPA on AWS plugins for backstage
contribute two new entity kinds to
support and model the AWS runtimes for
applications we've been discussing the
environment and environment provider
Concepts and these are also the names of
the new kinds that are contributed to
the backstage software catalog an
environment kind has one or more
environment provider kinds components
and resources such as AWS RDS databases
also have dependency relationships on
the environment kinds if you're not
familiar with the backstage entity model
I encourage you to read more about the
life of a backstage entity and the
system model at the URL on this
page we'd like our platform Engineers to
quickly create new environments based on
established templates directly from the
backstage UI therefore similar to
templates used by developers to create
new applications we're going to
contribute templates to Backstage for
creation of the new entity types we just
discussed let's take a closer look at
what would be included in a common
Repository representing software
template for environment
providers here on the left is a
directory structure of which you might
see in a repo for an ECS environment
provider template on the right is the
content of the catalog info yaml file
normally in the repository containing
template files you would find
placeholders for many of the property
values which would be substituted during
the scaffolding process here I've
updated the content with actual values
to make the context more
meaningful much of the ml file follows
the descriptor format for catalog
entities as described in the backstage
documentation some unique metadata
additions for the environment provider
include a prefix used when naming AWS
resources such as SSM parameter paths
environment type to indicate the type of
runtime supported by this environment
provider valid values include serverless
and ECS with additional support planned
for the future the AWS account and
region specify the account and region
region where this environment provider's
resources reside the environment role is
a role in the environment provider's
Target account which will be assumed
during the gitlab pipeline to provision
the environment
resources a series of metadata
properties use SSM parameter store keys
to pull configuration information at
runtime this is where additional
configuration information about the VPC
ECS cluster IM IM roles and audit table
is
stored finally there is a reference to
the confirmation stack which provisioned
the environment provider
infrastructure a gitlab CI yamamo file
is included in the template repository
to define the pipeline used to build and
deploy the environment provider
resources this is a standard gitlab
pipeline file and can be tailored to use
your own build conventions and processes
ultimately the pipeline will need to
perform actions to invoke the cdk or
terraform infrastructure code in this
example the actual cdk code to provision
the network and ECS resources is in a
shared pipeline line file in the common
cicd
folder the stack parameters properties
file is a key value properties file used
by the pipeline to load environment
variables required for pipeline
jobs lastly the template yaml file
captures how the template will present
its input form in the backstage UI and
the series of steps to perform when
scaffolding a new environment
provider most of the content in this
file is omitted here since the schema
and examples for template yl files are
well documented in the backstage
documentation at the URL
shown if you'd like to build out your
own environment provider templates and
the supporting infrastructure is code to
provision AWS resources I encourage you
to browse The open- Source repository
for the OPA on AWS solution at the URL
on this page you'll find a backstage D
reference folder containing several
examples actually used in the
solution the common subfolder is where
you will find infrastructure is code
with CD K and terraform samples this
code is pointed to and used by the
gitlab pipelines for environment
providers the templates subfolder
contains examples of environments and
environment providers similar to what
we've just walked
through that concludes the high level
overview of environments and environment
providers and how platform Engineers can
use Opa on AWS to simplify the creation
of standardized environments in the AWS
Cloud for their application developers
be sure to watch other videos in this
series to learn more about Opa and how
it can help you scale your
development
